articles.headline: C.E.O. Libraries Reveal Keys to Success
articles.snippet: Explore the personal libraries of successful chief executives and discover what makes them think, not compete.
articles.abstract: Explore the personal libraries of successful chief executives and discover what makes them think, not compete.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Moritz, the venture capitalist who built a personal $1.5 billion fortune discovering the likes of Google, YouTube, Yahoo and PayPal, and taking them public, may seem preternaturally in tune with new media. But it is the imprint of old media — books by the thousands sprawling through his Bay Area house — that occupies his mind.

articles.headline: After Six Years, the Global Trade Talks Are Just That: Talk
articles.snippet: Who is killing the Doha round of international trade talks? These days, it seems like everyone is guilty.
articles.abstract: Who is killing the Doha round of international trade talks? These days, it seems like everyone is guilty.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 20  Soon after Sept. 11, 2001, the United States helped start a round of global trade talks aimed at getting rich countries to lower trade barriers so that poor countries could prosper by exporting goods, not terrorism. But it was never that simple.

articles.headline: Google Pushes for Rules to Aid Wireless Plans
articles.snippet: The Internet giant, which may bid for a swath of U.S. airwaves, is lobbying to support a vision that could change how millions of Americans use cellphones.
articles.abstract: The Internet giant, which may bid for a swath of U.S. airwaves, is lobbying to support a vision that could change how millions of Americans use cellphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Google succeeds with federal regulators, it could change the way millions of Americans use their cellphones and how they connect to the Internet on their wireless devices.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Stephen Labaton

articles.headline: Court Tells U.S. to Reveal Data on Detainees at Guantánamo
articles.snippet: In a stinging legal challenge to the administration’s detention policies, a ruling requires virtually all information to be shared with defense lawyers.
articles.abstract: In a stinging legal challenge to the administration’s detention policies, a ruling requires virtually all information to be shared with defense lawyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ordered the government yesterday to turn over virtually all its information on Guantánamo detainees who are challenging their detention, rejecting an effort by the Justice Department to limit disclosures and setting the stage for new legal battles over the government’s reasons for holding the men indefinitely.

articles.headline: Musharraf Loses Fight Over Suspension of Judge
articles.snippet: A ruling was a blow to Pakistan’s president, who has been beset by Islamic militants and pro-democracy opponents.
articles.abstract: A ruling was a blow to Pakistan’s president, who has been beset by Islamic militants and pro-democracy opponents.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 20  Pakistan’s Supreme Court ruled Friday that the suspension of the country’s chief justice earlier this year by President Pervez Musharraf was illegal, dealing the president a strong rebuke and raising new questions about his ability to continue his rule past this year.

articles.headline: Debt Market Is Squeezing Private Equity
articles.snippet: Fueled by anxiety awakened by the mortgage loan crisis, private equity firms are finding it harder to borrow as investors demand better terms for loans and bonds.
articles.abstract: Fueled by anxiety awakened by the mortgage loan crisis, private equity firms are finding it harder to borrow as investors demand better terms for loans and bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: After two years of rapid-fire deal making, private equity firms are finding it harder to get the job done.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: China Shuts 3 Companies Over Safety of Products
articles.snippet: Chinese regulators said that the companies had exported mislabeled drug and tainted pet food ingredients.
articles.abstract: Chinese regulators said that the companies had exported mislabeled drug and tainted pet food ingredients.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, July 20 — The Chinese government moved on Friday to quell international concerns about the safety of its exports, announcing that it had revoked the licenses of three companies that made poisonous ingredients later used — with lethal results — in medicine and pet food.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Walt Bogdanich

articles.headline: Sober North Dakotans Hope to Legalize Hemp
articles.snippet: Farmers are part of a national movement to legalize growing a plant that is closely associated with marijuana.
articles.abstract: Farmers are part of a national movement to legalize growing a plant that is closely associated with marijuana.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSNABROCK, N.D.  David C. Monson seems an improbable soul to find at the leading edge of a national movement to legalize growing hemp, a plant that shares a species name, a genus type and, in many circles, a reputation, with marijuana.

articles.headline: New Leaders Say Pensive French Think Too Much
articles.snippet: In the country of the Enlightenment, President Nicolas Sarkozy’s government advocates hard work, not musing.
articles.abstract: In the country of the Enlightenment, President Nicolas Sarkozy’s government advocates hard work, not musing.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 21 — France is the country that produced the Enlightenment, Descartes’s one-liner, “I think, therefore I am,” and the solemn pontifications of Jean-Paul Sartre and other celebrity philosophers.

articles.headline: Africa, Offline: Waiting for the Web
articles.snippet: About 75 percent of African Internet traffic is routed through Britain, or even the United States, making it the least connected region in the world.
articles.abstract: About 75 percent of African Internet traffic is routed through Britain, or even the United States, making it the least connected region in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON a muggy day in Kigali in 2003, some of the highest-ranking officials in the Rwandan government, including President Paul Kagame, flanked an American businessman, Greg Wyler, as he boldly described how he could help turn their small country into a hub of Internet activity.

articles.headline: Is G.E. Too Big for Its Own Good?
articles.snippet: After six years of stagnation, pressure is mounting on the chief executive of General Electric to boost shares.
articles.abstract: After six years of stagnation, pressure is mounting on the chief executive of General Electric to boost shares.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVEN by the standards of a company that builds everything from light bulbs to power plants and straddles markets as varied as prime-time TV and commercial finance, General Electric’s mammoth project along the Hudson River north of Albany is staggering. The company plans to lay down more than 28,000 feet of rail and 267,000 square yards of plastic beside the river’s edge — all to haul nearly 400,000 tons of sediment from the bottom of the Hudson beginning in 2009, seven years and $500 million after G.E. agreed to undertake the job.

articles.headline: In a Volatile City, a Stern Line on Race and Politics
articles.snippet: More than any other Republican running for president, Rudolph W. Giuliani has confronted the question of race.
articles.abstract: More than any other Republican running for president, Rudolph W. Giuliani has confronted the question of race.
articles.lead_paragraph: Those were grim days for race relations in New York City, the early 1990s. There were nearly 2,000 murders each year, blacks and whites died in high-profile racial killings, and a riot held a divided Brooklyn neighborhood in thrall for three dangerous nights.

articles.headline: Setting Restaurant Records by Selling the Sizzle
articles.snippet: Tao Las Vegas, with $55.2 million in business last year, has set a new standard even for huge-volume restaurants.
articles.abstract: Tao Las Vegas, with $55.2 million in business last year, has set a new standard even for huge-volume restaurants.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  — There is the 20-foot golden Buddha, and enough velvet and silk swathing 60,000 square feet to evoke an Old West bordello. Ever-thumping music pumps in the dining room and two levels above, sending the stylish and scantily clad to the dance floor.

articles.headline: Ethiopia Is Said to Block Food to Rebel Region
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of people in a remote eastern part of the country are at risk of starvation, officials say.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people in a remote eastern part of the country are at risk of starvation, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 21 — The Ethiopian government is blockading emergency food aid and choking off trade to large swaths of a remote region in the eastern part of the country that is home to a rebel force, putting hundreds of thousands of people at risk of starvation, Western diplomats and humanitarian officials say.

articles.headline: Mr. Vranos Has a Deal for You
articles.snippet: It takes a special kind of cheek to ask investors at this moment to finance a new company specializing in subprime residential mortgage loans.
articles.abstract: It takes a special kind of cheek to ask investors at this moment to finance a new company specializing in subprime residential mortgage loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: HEDGE fund managers are not short on chutzpah, as a rule. But it takes a special kind of cheek to ask investors at this very tender moment in the housing market for $750 million to fund a new company specializing in subprime residential mortgage loans.

articles.headline: Record Failures at Oil Refineries Raise Gas Prices
articles.snippet: A third of the country’s oil refineries have reported disruptions like fires, power failures, leaks, spills and breakdowns this year.
articles.abstract: A third of the country’s oil refineries have reported disruptions like fires, power failures, leaks, spills and breakdowns this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil refineries across the country have been plagued by a record number of fires, power failures, leaks, spills and breakdowns this year, causing dozens of them to shut down temporarily or trim production. The disruptions are helping to drive gasoline prices to highs not seen since last summer’s records.

articles.headline: Drug Safety Critic Hurls Darts From the Inside
articles.snippet: Steven E. Nissen performs industry-financed research, but he has emerged as a Naderesque figure on drug safety.
articles.abstract: Steven E. Nissen performs industry-financed research, but he has emerged as a Naderesque figure on drug safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in the ’60s, when University of Michigan students were holding protests over civil rights and the Vietnam War, an undergraduate named Steven E. Nissen was at the center of the political dissent.

articles.headline: Bomb by Bomb, Japan Sheds Military Restraints
articles.snippet: Japan is blurring the line between defensive and offensive military power in spite of its pacifist Constitution, rattling nerves in northeast Asia.
articles.abstract: Japan is blurring the line between defensive and offensive military power in spite of its pacifist Constitution, rattling nerves in northeast Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANDERSEN AIR FORCE BASE, Guam  To take part in its annual exercises with the United States Air Force here last month, Japan practiced dropping 500-pound live bombs on Farallon de Medinilla, a tiny island in the western Pacific’s turquoise waters more than 150 miles north of here.

articles.headline: SunRocket Leaves Void for Callers on Internet
articles.snippet: The collapse of SunRocket, an Internet telephone company that went out of business without warning, raises questions about what responsibility such companies have to their customers.
articles.abstract: The collapse of SunRocket, an Internet telephone company that went out of business without warning, raises questions about what responsibility such companies have to their customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Waiting for an important phone call can be stressful. As Marshel Emery can attest, it is doubly so when your phone company has just ceased to exist.

articles.headline: Unlikely Adversary Arises to Criticize Detainee Hearings
articles.snippet: Stephen E. Abraham, a decorated reserve Army intelligence officer, may have played a key role in the Supreme Court’s reversal of its stance on Guantánamo Bay prisoners.
articles.abstract: Stephen E. Abraham, a decorated reserve Army intelligence officer, may have played a key role in the Supreme Court’s reversal of its stance on Guantánamo Bay prisoners.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — Stephen E. Abraham’s assignment to the Pentagon unit that runs the hearings at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, seemed a perfect fit.

articles.headline: A Family Meets Today to Hear the Complexities of a Bid for Dow Jones
articles.snippet: As the Bancroft family assembles to consider selling Dow Jones & Company, money will not be the only issue on the table.
articles.abstract: As the Bancroft family assembles to consider selling Dow Jones & Company, money will not be the only issue on the table.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it assembles at the Boston Hilton today to consider selling Dow Jones & Company and its main prize, The Wall Street Journal, to Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, the controlling Bancroft clan faces some stark choices.

articles.headline: Let the Sun Shine
articles.snippet: For decades, journalists seeking Freedom of Information requests have  been stymied by agencies that flout the law through recalcitrance or ineptitude.
articles.abstract: For decades, journalists seeking Freedom of Information requests have  been stymied by agencies that flout the law through recalcitrance or ineptitude.
articles.lead_paragraph: We live in a nakedly transparent age. Celebrities live out loud, companies routinely have their business spilled all over the Web and anybody can find out an awful lot about you or me with a click of the mouse.

articles.headline: Barbie Gets Another Accessory: An MP3 Player and More Stuff on Her Web Site
articles.snippet: A new doll hitting retail shelves is familiar in many ways, but this Barbie is a roundabout way of charging for online content.
articles.abstract: A new doll hitting retail shelves is familiar in many ways, but this Barbie is a roundabout way of charging for online content.
articles.lead_paragraph: First, Barbie had Ken. Now, Barbie has a docking station.

articles.headline: Oops! ...They Did It Again
articles.snippet: Amid financial setbacks in the music industry, the Zomba Label Group is on a hot streak, with hits from performers like Justin Timberlake, R. Kelly and T-Pain.
articles.abstract: Amid financial setbacks in the music industry, the Zomba Label Group is on a hot streak, with hits from performers like Justin Timberlake, R. Kelly and T-Pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 22 — Barry Weiss, the president of the Zomba Label Group, had been chatting with a guest at his label’s recent party at the Ritual club here when he abruptly cut off conversation and strode toward the dance floor.

articles.headline: Study of Wrongful Convictions Raises Questions Beyond DNA
articles.snippet: A study suggests that there are thousands of people serving long sentences for crimes they did not commit but who have no hope that DNA can clear them.
articles.abstract: A study suggests that there are thousands of people serving long sentences for crimes they did not commit but who have no hope that DNA can clear them.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April, Jerry Miller, an Illinois man who served 24 years for a rape he did not commit, became the 200th American prisoner cleared by DNA evidence. His case, like the 199 others, represented a catastrophic failure of the criminal justice system.
